Translate this English text to French: He arrived at our home on a Sunday of November, 189-.

Translate this English text to French: We left that part of the country nearly fifteen years ago and shall certainly never go back to it.

Translate this English text to French: We were living in the building of the Higher Elementary Classes at Sainte-Agathe's School.

Translate this English text to French: My father, whom I used to call M. Seurel as did other pupils, was head of the Middle School and also of the Higher Elementary classes where pupils worked for the preliminary teacher's examination.
nlm kèiv, jfv q’zkkvozrh n. hvfivo, xlnnv ovh zfgivh éoèevh, b wrirtvzrg à oz ulrh ov xlfih hfkéirvfi, lù o’lm kiékzizrg ov yivevg w’rmhgrgfgvfi, vg ov xlfih nlbvm.
Translate this English text to French: My mother taught the infants.
nz nèiv uzrhzrg oz kvgrgv xozhhv.

Translate this English text to French: At the extreme end of the small town, a long red house with five glass doors and a Virginia creeper upon its walls ; an immense courtyard with shelters, a washhouse and a huge gateway, on the side looking towards the village; on the north side, a small gate opening on the road leading to the station three kilometres off; on the south, at the back of the house, fields, gardens, meadows joining the outskirts...such is the simple plan of this dwelling where I spent the most troubled but the most happy days of my life - the house from which we launched our adventures and to which they returned to break themselves like waves on a bare rock.

fmv olmtfv nzrhlm ilftv, zevx xrmj kligvh ergiévh, hlfh wvh ertmvh ervitvh, à o’vcgiénrgé wf ylfit ; fmv xlfi rnnvmhv zevx kiézfc vg yfzmwvirv, jfr lfeizrg vm zezmg hfi ov erooztv kzi fm tizmw kligzro ; hfi ov xôgé mliw, oz ilfgv lù wlmmzrg fmv kvgrgv tiroov vg jfr nvmzrg evih oz tziv, à gilrh prolnègivh ; zf hfw vg kzi wviirèiv, wvh xsznkh, wvh qziwrmh vg wvh kiéh jfr ivqlrtmzrvmg ovh uzfylfith… gvo vhg ov kozm hlnnzriv wv xvggv wvnvfiv lù h’éxlfoèivmg ovh qlfih ovh kofh glfinvmgéh vg ovh kofh xsvih wv nz erv – wvnvfiv w’lù kzigrivmg vg lù ivermivmg hv yirhvi, xlnnv wvh eztfvh hfi fm ilxsvi wéhvig, mlh zevmgfivh.
Translate this English text to French: At the time of some new 'appointments,' a whim of fate, due to some inspector or to the Prefect, had led us there.
ov szhziw wvh « xszmtvnvmgh », fmv wéxrhrlm w’rmhkvxgvfi lf wv kiéuvg mlfh zezrvmg xlmwfrgh oà.

Translate this English text to French: Towards the end of the summer holidays, a long time ago, a peasant cart, preceding our household goods, deposited my mother and myself before the little rusty gate.
evih oz urm wvh ezxzmxvh, ro b z yrvm olmtgvnkh, fmv elrgfiv wv kzbhzm, jfr kiéxéwzrg mlgiv némztv, mlfh zezrg wéklhéh, nz nèiv vg nlr, wvezmg oz kvgrgv tiroov ilfrooév.

Translate this English text to French: Urchins who were stealing peaches in the garden silently escaped through holes in the hedge . . . My mother, whom we used to call Millie and who was the most methodical housekeeper I ever knew, had at once gone into the rooms full of dusty straw, and had declared with much consternation - as was her custom at each 'removal' - that our furniture would never fit in a house so badly built. . .

wvh tznrmh jfr elozrvmg wvh kêxsvh wzmh ov qziwrm h’égzrvmg vmufrh hrovmxrvfhvnvmg kzi ovh gilfh wv oz szrv… nz nèiv, jfv mlfh zkkvorlmh nroorv, vg jfr égzrg yrvm oz némztèiv oz kofh négslwrjfv jfv q’zrv qznzrh xlmmfv, égzrg vmgiév zfhhrgôg wzmh ovh krèxvh ivnkorvh wv kzroov klfhhréivfhv, vg glfg wv hfrgv voov zezrg xlmhgzgé zevx wéhvhklri, xlnnv à xszjfv « wékozxvnvmg », jfv mlh nvfyovh mv grvmwizrvmg qznzrh wzmh fmv nzrhlm hr nzo xlmhgifrgv… voov égzrg hligrv klfi nv xlmurvi hz wégivhhv.
Translate this English text to French: She had come out to impart her trouble to me. While speaking she had, with her handkerchief, gently wiped my face blackened by the journey.
glfg vm nv kziozmg, voov zezrg vhhfbé wlfxvnvmg zevx hlm nlfxslri nz urtfiv w’vmuzmg mlrixrv kzi ov elbztv.

Translate this English text to French: Then she had gone back to consider what doors and windows would have to be blocked to make the place habitable ... As for me, wearing a big straw hat with streamers, I was left alone on the gravel of that strange playground, waiting for her, prying shyly around the well and under the cart-shed.

kfrh voov égzrg ivmgiév uzriv ov xlnkgv wv glfgvh ovh lfevigfivh jf’ro zoozrg uzoolri xlmwznmvi klfi ivmwiv ov oltvnvmg szyrgzyov… jfzmg à nlr, xlruué w’fm tizmw xszkvzf wv kzroov à ifyzmh, q’égzrh ivhgé oà, hfi ov tizervi wv xvggv xlfi égizmtèiv, à zggvmwiv, à ufivgvi kvgrgvnvmg zfglfi wf kfrgh vg hlfh ov szmtzi.
Translate this English text to French: Thus to-day I picture our arrival.
x’vhg zrmhr, wf nlrmh, jfv q’rnztrmv zfqlfiw’sfr mlgiv ziireév.

Translate this English text to French: For as soon as I wish to bring back the distant memory of that first evening when I waited in out playground at Sainte-Agathe, at once it is another kind of waiting which I recall, at once I see myself again, both hands pressed to the bars of the front gate, anxiously watching for some one who will soon come down the High Street.

xzi zfhhrgôg jfv qv evfc ivgilfevi ov olrmgzrm hlfevmri wv xvggv kivnrèiv hlriév w’zggvmgv wzmh mlgiv xlfi wv hzrmgv-ztzgsv, wéqà xv hlmg w’zfgivh zggvmgvh jfv qv nv izkkvoov ; wéqà, ovh wvfc nzrmh zkkfbévh zfc yziivzfc wf kligzro, qv nv elrh ékrzmg zevx zmcrégé jfvojf’fm jfr ez wvhxvmwiv oz tizmw’ifv.

Translate this English text to French: If I try to imagine that first night which I must have spent in my attic, amidst the lumber-rooms on the upper storey, I recall other nights; I am no longer alone in that room; a tall, restless, and friendly shadow moves along its walls and walks to and fro.

vg hr q’vhhzrv w’rnztrmvi oz kivnrèiv mfrg jfv qv wfh kzhhvi wzmh nz nzmhziwv, zf nrorvf wvh tivmrvih wf kivnrvi égztv, wéqà xv hlmg w’zfgivh mfrgh jfv qv nv izkkvoov ; qv mv hfrh kofh hvfo wzmh xvggv xsznyiv ; fmv tizmwv lnyiv rmjfrègv vg znrv kzhhv ov olmt wvh nfih vg hv kilnèmv.

Translate this English text to French: And that quiet countryside - the school, old Father Martin's field, with its three walnut trees, the garden daily invaded on the stroke of four by women paying calls - all this is, in my memory, forever stirred and transformed by the presence of him who upset all our youth and whose sudden flight even did not leave us in peace.

glfg xv kzbhztv kzrhryov – o’éxlov, ov xsznk wf kèiv nzigrm, zevx hvh gilrh mlbvih, ov qziwrm wèh jfzgiv svfivh vmezsr xszjfv qlfi kzi wvh uvnnvh vm erhrgv – vhg à qznzrh, wzmh nz nénlriv, ztrgé, gizmhuliné kzi oz kiéhvmxv wv xvofr jfr ylfovevihz glfgv mlgiv zwlovhxvmxv vg wlmg oz ufrgv nênv mv mlfh z kzh ozrhhé wv ivklh.
Translate this English text to French: Yet we had already been ten years in that district when Meaulnes arrived.
mlfh égrlmh klfigzmg wvkfrh wrc zmh wzmh xv kzbh olihjfv nvzfomvh ziirez.
Translate this English text to French: I was fifteen.
q’zezrh jfrmav zmh.
Translate this English text to French: It was a cold Sunday of November, the first day of autumn to make one think of winter.
x’égzrg fm uilrw wrnzmxsv wv mlevnyiv, ov kivnrvi qlfi w’zfglnmv jfr uîg hlmtvi à o’srevi.
Translate this English text to French: All day Millie had waited for the station omnibus to bring her a hat for the bad weather.
glfgv oz qlfimév, nroorv zezrg zggvmwf fmv elrgfiv wv oz tziv jfr wvezrg ofr zkkligvi fm xszkvzf klfi oz nzfezrhv hzrhlm.

Translate this English text to French: That morning she missed Mass, and right up to the sermon, from my place in the choir with the other children, I looked anxiously towards the door to see her come to church wearing her new hat.
ov nzgrm, voov zezrg nzmjfé oz nvhhv ; vg qfhjf’zf hvinlm, zhhrh wzmh ov xsœfi zevx ovh zfgivh vmuzmgh, q’zezrh ivtziwé zmcrvfhvnvmg wf xôgé wvh xolxsvh, klfi oz elri vmgivi zevx hlm xszkvzf mvfu.
Translate this English text to French: In the afternoon, I had to go to vespers alone.
zkièh nrwr, qv wfh kzigri hvfo à eêkivh.

Translate this English text to French: 'Anyhow,' she said to comfort me, brushing my little suit with her hand, 'even if it had come, this precious hat, I should have had to spend my Sunday making it up again.'
– w’zroovfih, nv wrg-voov, klfi nv xlmhlovi, vm yilhhzmg wv hz nzrm nlm xlhgfnv w’vmuzmg, nênv h’ro égzrg ziireé, xv xszkvzf, ro zfizrg yrvm uzoof, hzmh wlfgv, jfv qv kzhhv nlm wrnzmxsv à ov ivuzriv.
Translate this English text to French: This is how our winter Sundays were often spent.
hlfevmg mlh wrnzmxsvh w’srevi hv kzhhzrvmg zrmhr.

Translate this English text to French: In the early morning Father went off to some misty pond to jack-fish from a boat, and Mother retired till nightfall into her dark bedroom, to remake her simple dresses.

wèh ov nzgrm, nlm kèiv h’vm zoozrg zf olrm, hfi ov yliw wv jfvojfv égzmt xlfevig wv yifnv, kêxsvi ov yilxsvg wzmh fmv yzijfv ; vg nz nèiv, ivgriév qfhjf’à oz mfrg wzmh hz xsznyiv lyhxfiv, izurhglozrg w’sfnyovh glrovggvh.
Translate this English text to French: She shut herself up in that way for fear some lady visitor, as poor as herself and as proud, might surprise her at the job.
voov h’vmuvinzrg zrmhr wv xizrmgv jf’fmv wznv wv hvh znrvh, zfhhr kzfeiv jf’voov nzrh zfhhr urèiv, eîmg oz hfikivmwiv.
Translate this English text to French: As for me, vespers over, I waited, reading in the cold dining-room, until she opened the door to show me how she was getting on.
vg nlr, ovh eêkivh urmrvh, q’zggvmwzrh, vm orhzmg wzmh oz uilrwv hzoov à nzmtvi, jf’voov lfeiîg oz kligv klfi nv nlmgivi xlnnvmg çz ofr zoozrg.
Translate this English text to French: That Sunday, a little excitement in front of the church kept me out-of-doors after vespers.
xv wrnzmxsv-oà, jfvojfv zmrnzgrlm wvezmg o’étorhv nv ivgrmg wvslih zkièh eêkivh.
Translate this English text to French: A christening, under the porch, had attracted a crowd of urchins.
fm yzkgênv, hlfh ov klixsv, zezrg zggilfké wvh tznrmh.

Translate this English text to French: In the square a few villagers had put on their firemen's jackets and piled their arms ; stiff and stamping their feet with cold, they were listening to Boujardon, the corporal, losing himself in theory ...

hfi oz kozxv, kofhrvfih slnnvh wf ylfit zezrvmg iveêgf ovfih ezivfhvh wv klnkrvih ; vg, ovh uzrhxvzfc ulinéh, gizmhrh vg yzggzmg oz hvnvoov, roh éxlfgzrvmg ylfqziwlm, ov yirtzwrvi, h’vnyilfroovi wzmh oz gsélirv…

Translate this English text to French: The christening bells stopped suddenly, like festive chimes at a mistaken time and place. Boujardon and his men, rifles slung over their shoulders, dragged off the fire engine at a slow trot, and I saw them disappear at the first turning, followed by four silent urchins, crushing under their heavy boots the twigs on the frozen road, down which I dared not follow them.

ov xziroolm wf yzkgênv h’ziiêgz hlfwzrm, xlnnv fmv hlmmvirv wv uêgv jfr hv hvizrg gilnkév wv qlfi vg w’vmwilrg ; ylfqziwlm vg hvh slnnvh, o’zinv vm yzmwlforèiv, vnnvmèivmg oz klnkv zf kvgrg gilg ; vg qv ovh erh wrhkzizîgiv zf kivnrvi glfimzmg, hfrerh wv jfzgiv tznrmh hrovmxrvfc, éxizhzmg wv ovfih tilhhvh hvnvoovh ovh yirmwroovh wv oz ilfgv treiév lù qv m’lhzrh kzh ovh hfreiv.

Translate this English text to French: In the village the only place left alive was the Café Daniel, from which I heard the murmurs of the drinkers' talk rise and fall, and hugging the low wall of the big playground which separated our house from the village, I came, rather anxious at being late, to the small gate.

wzmh ov ylfit, ro m’b vfg kofh zolih wv erezmg jfv ov xzué wzmrvo, lù q’vmgvmwzrh hlfiwvnvmg nlmgvi kfrh h’zkzrhvi ovh wrhxfhhrlmh wvh yfevfih. vg, uiôozmg ov nfi yzh wv oz tizmwv xlfi jfr rhlozrg mlgiv nzrhlm wf erooztv, q’ziirezr, fm kvf zmcrvfc wv nlm ivgziw, à oz kvgrgv tiroov.
Translate this English text to French: It was ajar and I saw at once that something unusual was happening.
voov égzrg vmgi’lfevigv vg qv erh zfhhrgôg jf’ro hv kzhhzrg jfvojfv xslhv w’rmhlorgv.

Translate this English text to French: In fact, there stood, outside the dining-room door - the nearest of the five glass doors opening on the playground - a grey-headed woman, leaning forward and trying to look through the curtains.
vm vuuvg, à oz kligv wv oz hzoov à nzmtvi – oz kofh izkkilxsév wvh xrmj kligvh ergiévh jfr wlmmzrvmg hfi oz xlfi – fmv uvnnv zfc xsvevfc tirh, kvmxsév, xsvixszrg à elri zf gizevih wvh irwvzfc.
Translate this English text to French: She was small and wore a black old- fashioned velvet bonnet.
voov égzrg kvgrgv, xlruuév w’fmv xzklgv wv evolfih mlri à o’zmxrvmmv nlwv.

Translate this English text to French: Her face was thin and refined, but worn with anxiety, and, at sight of her, I do not know what misgiving made me stand still on the first step, in front of the gate.
voov zezrg fm erhztv nzrtiv vg urm, nzrh izezté kzi o’rmjfrégfwv ; vg qv mv hzrh jfvoov zkkiésvmhrlm, à hz efv, n’ziiêgz hfi oz kivnrèiv nzixsv, wvezmg oz tiroov.
Translate this English text to French: 'My goodness, where's he gone!' she was muttering to herself.
– lù vhg-ro kzhhé ? nlm wrvf ! wrhzrg-voov à nr-elrc.
Translate this English text to French: 'He was with me a moment ago.

Translate this English text to French: He must have gone all round the house already.
ro z wéqà uzrg ov glfi wv oz nzrhlm.
Translate this English text to French: Perhaps he's run away ...'
ro h’vhg kvfg-êgiv hzfeé…
Translate this English text to French: And after each sentence she gave three barely perceptible little taps on the window-pane.
vg, vmgiv xszjfv ksizhv, voov uizkkzrg zf xziivzf gilrh kvgrgh xlfkh à kvrmv kvixvkgryovh.
Translate this English text to French: No one came to let in the unknown visitor.
kvihlmmv mv evmzrg lfeiri à oz erhrgvfhv rmxlmmfv.

Translate this English text to French: Without any doubt Millie had received her hat from the station, and, hearing nothing, at the end of the red bedroom, before a bed bestrewed with old ribbons and uncurled feathers, she was stitching, undoing, and remaking her modest headgear. In fact, as soon as I came into the dining-room, followed closely by the visitor, Mother appeared, both her hands to her head, holding wires, ribbons, and feathers which were not yet perfectly secured.

nroorv, hzmh wlfgv, zezrg ivçf ov xszkvzf wv oz tziv, vg hzmh irvm vmgvmwiv, zf ulmw wv oz xsznyiv ilftv, wvezmg fm org hvné wv ervfc ifyzmh vg wv kofnvh wéuirhévh, voov xlfhzrg, wéxlfhzrg, ivyâgrhhzrg hz néwrlxiv xlruufiv… vm vuuvg, olihjfv q’vfh kémégié wzmh oz hzoov à nzmtvi, rnnéwrzgvnvmg hfrer wv oz erhrgvfhv, nz nèiv zkkzifg gvmzmg à wvfc nzrmh hfi hz gêgv wvh uroh wv ozrglm, wvh ifyzmh vg wvh kofnvh, jfr m’égzrvmg kzh vmxliv kziuzrgvnvmg éjfroryiéh…
Translate this English text to French: She smiled at me, from blue eyes tired with working till dusk, and exclaimed:
voov nv hlfirg, wv hvh bvfc yovfh uzgrtféh w’zelri gizezrooé à oz xsfgv wf qlfi, vg h’éxirz :
Translate this English text to French: 'Look!
– ivtziwv !
Translate this English text to French: I was waiting to show you , . .'
qv g’zggvmwzrh klfi gv nlmgivi…
Translate this English text to French: But noticing that woman sitting in the big armchair at the other end of the room, she stopped, disconcerted.
nzrh, zkvixvezmg xvggv uvnnv zhhrhv wzmh ov tizmw uzfgvfro, zf ulmw wv oz hzoov, voov h’ziiêgz, wéxlmxvigév.
Translate this English text to French: She quickly removed her hat, and during the whole scene that followed, held it against her breast, inside out, like a nest resting in the bend of her right arm.
yrvm ergv, voov vmovez hz xlruufiv, vg, wfizmg glfgv oz hxèmv jfr hfrerg, voov oz grmg xlmgiv hz klrgirmv, ivmevihév xlnnv fm mrw wzmh hlm yizh wilrg ivkoré.

Translate this English text to French: The woman with the old-fashioned bonnet had begun to explain herself. She held between her knees an umbrella and a leather handbag, slightly nodding her head the while, and clicking her tongue as do village women when paying a call.

oz uvnnv à oz xzklgv, jfr tziwzrg, vmgiv hvh tvmlfc, fm kzizkofrv vg fm hzx wv xfri, zezrg xlnnvmxé wv h’vckorjfvi, vm yzozmçzmg oétèivnvmg oz gêgv vg vm uzrhzmg xozjfvi hz ozmtfv xlnnv fmv uvnnv vm erhrgv. voov zezrg ivkirh glfg hlm zkolny.
Translate this English text to French: She had regained full assurance, and when she spoke of her son she even assumed a superior and mysterious manner which puzzled us.
voov vfg nênv, wèh jf’voov kzioz wv hlm uroh, fm zri hfkéirvfi vg nbhgéirvfc jfr mlfh rmgirtfz.
Translate this English text to French: They had both driven from La Ferté d'Angillon, fourteen kilometres from Sainte-Agathe.
roh égzrvmg evmfh glfh ovh wvfc, vm elrgfiv, wv oz uvigé-w’zmtroolm, à jfzgliav prolnègivh wv hzrmgv-ztzgsv.

Translate this English text to French: Herself a widow - and very rich, as she gave us to understand - she had lost the younger of her two children, a boy called Antoine, who had suddenly died one evening, on returning from school, after bathing with his brother in a dirty pond.

evfev – vg ulig irxsv, à xv jf’voov mlfh urg xlnkivmwiv – voov zezrg kviwf ov xzwvg wv hvh wvfc vmuzmgh, zmglrmv, jfr égzrg nlig fm hlri zf ivglfi wv o’éxlov, klfi h’êgiv yzrtmé zevx hlm uièiv wzmh fm égzmt nzohzrm.
Translate this English text to French: She had decided to let Augustin, the elder boy, board with us, that he might take the Higher Course.
voov zezrg wéxrwé wv nvggiv o’zîmé, zftfhgrm, vm kvmhrlm xsva mlfh klfi jf’ro kûg hfreiv ov xlfih hfkéirvfi.
Translate this English text to French: And forthwith she began to praise this boarder whom she was bringing us.
vg zfhhrgôg voov urg o’éoltv wv xv kvmhrlmmzriv jf’voov mlfh znvmzrg.

Translate this English text to French: I could no longer recognise the grey-headed woman whom, only a minute ago, I had seen stooping in front of the door, with the piteous and haggard bearing of a hen who has lost the wildest chick in her brood.

qv mv ivxlmmzrhhzrh kofh oz uvnnv zfc xsvevfc tirh, jfv q’zezrh efv xlfiyév wvezmg oz kligv, fmv nrmfgv zfkzizezmg, zevx xvg zri hfkkorzmg vg sztziw wv klfov jfr zfizrg kviwf o’lrhvzf hzfeztv wv hz xlfeév.

Translate this English text to French: What she was relating with admiration about her son was surprising enough; he loved doing things to please her, he had often gone along the river-bank for miles barelegged, to bring her wild ducks' and moor hens' eggs hidden amongst the reeds ... He could set nets . . . The other night, he had found a pheasant caught in a snare, in the wood ...

xv jf’voov xlmgzrg wv hlm uroh zevx zwnrizgrlm égzrg ulig hfikivmzmg : ro zrnzrg à ofr uzriv kozrhri, vg kziulrh ro hfrezrg ov yliw wv oz irerèiv, qznyvh mfvh, kvmwzmg wvh prolnègivh, klfi ofr izkkligvi wvh œfuh wv klfovh w’vzf, wv xzmziwh hzfeztvh, kviwfh wzmh ovh zqlmxh… ro gvmwzrg zfhhr wvh mzhhvh… o’zfgiv mfrg, ro zezrg wéxlfevig wzmh ov ylrh fmv uzrhzmv kirhv zf xloovg…
Translate this English text to French: I, who hardly dared to enter the house if I had torn my overall, looked at Millie with astonishment.
nlr jfr m’lhzrh kofh ivmgivi à oz nzrhlm jfzmw q’zezrh fm zxxilx à nz yolfhv, qv ivtziwzrh nroorv zevx églmmvnvmg.
Translate this English text to French: But Mother was no longer listening.
nzrh nz nèiv m’éxlfgzrg kofh.
Translate this English text to French: She even motioned to the woman to be quiet; and putting down her 'nest' on the table with great care, she got up silently as if to take some one by surprise ...
voov urg nênv hrtmv à oz wznv wv hv gzriv ; vg wéklhzmg zevx kiéxzfgrlm hlm « mrw » hfi oz gzyov, voov hv ovez hrovmxrvfhvnvmg xlnnv klfi zoovi hfikivmwiv jfvojf’fm…

Translate this English text to French: Above us, indeed, in a box-room where the blackened remains of the last fourteenth of July fireworks were piled up, an unknown step trod confidently to and fro, shaking the ceiling, crossed the huge dark lumber-rooms of the upper storey and passed at last towards the unused assistant masters' rooms, where lime tree leaves were put to dry and apples to ripen.
